To achieve higher yields of dimethyl carbonate (DMC), it is crucial to have precise control of reaction conditions and to develop advanced catalysts with synergistic interactions at active sites. In this work, we synthesized a series of alkali-modified MOF-808 (Ce) catalysts by varying NaOH concentrations (0–1.0 M), followed by carbonation to yield the advanced catalysts—M-CeO₂-CX. Our evaluations of catalytic performance revealed that a 0.5 M NaOH alkaline environment (M-CeO₂-C0.5) was the most effective in breaking the non-covalent interactions within Ce-BTC ligands. Comprehensive characterization further confirmed that M-CeO₂-C0.5 exhibited markedly increased oxygen vacancies and higher densities of basic sites. Both of them are pivotal for enhancing CO₂ activation, leading to superior catalytic performance. Particularly, it was also applied, for the first time, in the direct synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO₂ without a dehydrating agent. Using Plackett-Burman (PB) and Box–Behnken Design (BBD) experimental techniques, we demonstrated that thermodynamic forces significantly outweighed kinetic effects in driving the reaction. Additionally, predictive yield models were developed and rigorously validated, identifying optimal conditions that resulted in a DMC yield of 24.61 mmol/g cat•h. Remarkably, the catalyst retained 97.88 % of its initial activity after 12 cycles, underscoring its exceptional stability and promising industrial scalability. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Alkaline etching PB and BBD experiment Thermodynamic parameters Yield prediction models M-CeO₂-CX 1 Introduction Carbon neutrality has become a focus on the global agenda, and carbon dioxide (CO₂) is recognized as an abundant carbon waste. Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is widely used as a solvent in lithium-ion battery electrolytes, with an annual demand of 20,000 tons [1]. Additionally, it serves as a sustainable precursor for polycarbonate plastics, which currently holds a global market of 4.5 million tons [2,3,4]. For each mole of DMC produced, one mole of CO₂ can potentially be utilized. Therefore, the direct synthesis of DMC from CO₂ and methanol has garnered considerable interest from researchers. The direct synthesis of DMC is facilitated by the synergistic action of oxygen vacancies (OVs) and acid-base sites on the catalyst surface. Among heterogeneous catalysts, metal oxides are considered the most promising candidates, owing to their tunable crystal structures and high acidity-basicity [5]. By modulating the surface OVs on CeO₂, the lattice oxygen (OL) surrounding the OVs clusters acts as Lewis basic sites, while the two adjacent Ce³⁺ ions function as Lewis acidic sites [6,7]. A major challenge in the title reaction lies in activating CO₂ molecules (ΔH = 16.74 kJ/mol), which is inherently tricky [8]. To overcome this, widely adopted strategies, such as single-element doping in CeGa [9] catalysts and co-doping in Ce₁Ga₀.₂Ti₀.₀₂ [10] catalysts, aim to fine-tune the catalyst's acid-base properties and OVs concentration. These modifications enhance CO₂ activation into reactive intermediates, thus promoting its efficient conversion into DMC. Notably, G. Laugel [11] proposed using solid bases to enhance CO₂ activation, as strong acids may lead to methanol dehydration, thereby reducing the formation of methoxy intermediates, which hinders the direct synthesis of DMC. In a related study, grafting Ce onto base-treated β-zeolite resulted in the CB-5 composite catalyst, which showed a significant increase in DMC yield. This increase was driven by the synergistic interaction between surface acid-base sites and OVs [12]. Since the initial report on the synthesis of porous carbon utilizing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as templates [13], a wide array of MOF-derived products has been developed for catalytic applications [14,15]. MOFs exhibit crystalline microporous characteristics [16], providing innovative pathways for the development of metal nanoparticle/carbon composite materials as heterogeneous catalysts [17,18]. However, the constrained pore size and inadequate chemical stability significantly limit their range of catalytic applications [11,19,20]. This limitation primarily stems from the non-covalent interactions between organic ligands during the synthesis of M(III)/M(IV)-MOFs [21,22], which may either be too weak to withstand the harsh conditions required for their synthesis or excessively strong to be cleaved, leading to diminished solubility in solvents. Mitsunori Kitta et al. [23] synthesized various compositions of Fe-Co bimetallic MOFs through a sodium hydroxide-assisted method, demonstrating remarkable efficacy as catalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) during stability assessments. Xiu-Liang Lv et al. [24] prepared MOF analogues of different rare earth metals in aqueous solutions across a range of pH levels, thereby revealing the potential of these materials for gas adsorption and catalytic applications. Among the materials tested, PCN-2020(Ce) exhibited exceptional catalytic performance in CO₂ conversion reactions. Fei Wang et al. [25] synthesized Mn-doped CeO₂ by pyrolyzing Mn-modified Ce-BTC, while Zeyu Jiang et al. [26] calcined Ce-BTC under various atmospheric conditions to produce rod-like nano CeO₂ catalysts. Characterization results provided insights into the structure-activity relationships of the catalysts, revealing that the porous CeO₂ nanostructures derived from these two distinct strategies exhibited enhanced surface OVs and acid-base sites, which significantly facilitated CO₂ adsorption and activation. However, neither study addressed the potential benefits of employing a sodium hydroxide-assisted strategy for ligand assembly during catalyst preparation, which could help overcome the issues of small pore size and poor chemical stability in CeO₂ catalysts. From what has been discussed above, the design of MOF-assembled catalysts featuring optimally strong non-covalent interactions among organic ligands, such as BTC, under certain alkaline conditions is crucial for further improving DMC synthesis yields. Another promising avenue of research involves exploring the kinetics and thermodynamics of chemical reactions between alcohols and CO₂, an area marked by considerable complexity. Precise control of the feed ratio is critical, given that these reactions display substantial activation volumes. As the system temperature exceeds the boiling point of the reactants, complete vaporization occurs, triggering a sharp rise in system pressure. In this scenario, the feed ratio becomes a key determinant influencing pressure, which, in turn, directly affects the rate constant [27]. Moreover, as this is a gas-solid reaction, it is essential to consider both internal and external diffusion phases of reactants and products on the catalyst surface, particularly in laboratory-scale experiments. However, incorporating diffusion effects complicates the analysis of intrinsic kinetics. Determining an optimal rotation rate is vital to mitigate this challenge, as it minimizes external diffusion limitations by enhancing molecular collision frequency and improving mass transfer within the catalyst's micropores. Striking this balance is crucial for an accurate assessment of reaction kinetics. Response Surface Methodology (RSM) [28,29,30,31]is a powerful statistical and mathematical approach designed to streamline experimental design and optimize the influence of process variables. By reducing the number of experiments necessary to achieve desired outcomes, RSM enhances efficiency in experimental research. One of its key strengths is the ability to evaluate the interactive effects of two or more variables on the response variable, providing deeper insight into complex relationships between factors. Widely applied for the optimization of analytical methods, RSM is built upon the fitting of polynomial equations to experimental data, offering a robust framework for modeling [32]. This approach proves particularly useful when one or more responses are impacted by multiple variables, allowing for precise adjustments to optimize desired results. Herein, we focus on improving CO₂ activation and enhancing the stability of MOF-derived catalysts, thereby advancing the industrialization of DMC synthesis and cerium oxide-based catalysts. We synthesized MOF-derived CeO₂ catalysts under various alkaline conditions. The activity evaluation experiments revealed that a 0.5 M NaOH alkaline environment was most conducive to breaking the non-covalent interactions between Ce-BTC organic ligands, resulting in a high-performance CeO₂ catalyst. We further compared the catalytic activities of CeO₂ catalysts prepared using different synthesis methods, including reflux and hydrothermal methods. A series of physicochemical characterizations, including X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area analysis, and CO₂ temperature-programmed desorption (CO₂-TPD), confirmed that the microporous defect-derived strategy effectively increases the oxygen vacancy concentration in the catalysts, enhancing CO₂ adsorption and activation capacity. Notably, through Plackett-Burman (PB) and Box–Behnken Design (BBD) experiments, we thoroughly investigated the kinetic and thermodynamic properties of the reaction. The results demonstrated that thermodynamic factors dominate the DMC synthesis, while kinetic factors have relatively less influence. We used RSM to analyze the interaction between influencing factors further, leading to the development of a predictive model for DMC yield. The optimized reaction conditions predicted a DMC yield of 24.61 mmol/g.cat. h. Additionally, catalyst recycling tests indicated that after 12 cycles, the catalyst retained 97.88 % of its initial activity, demonstrating excellent long-term stability. These findings provide new insights into the design and synthesis of MOF-based catalysts and offer a promising catalytic system for the industrial production of DMC. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Preparation of MOF-808(Ce)-X and M-CeO2-CX Initially, 14.7 g of trimesic acid was dissolved in a solution comprising 70 mL of deionized water and 70 mL of ethanol. Separately, 30.38 g of Ce(NO₃)₃·6H₂O was dissolved in 315 mL of deionized water. The two solutions were combined, and then carefully adding an accurately measured quantity of NaOH to adjust the alkalinity to a concentration of X M. The resulting mixture was covered with plastic wrap and heated in a water bath at 70 °C with vigorous stirring for 1 h, during which it transformed into a milky suspension. The solid product was then separated from the liquid phase via centrifugation and subjected to three alternate washes with deionized water and ethanol. Afterwards, the solid was dried in an oven at 100 °C for 10 h to obtain the MOF-808(Ce)-X sample. This sample was then calcined in a muffle furnace at a heating rate of 3 °C/min until reaching 460 °C, where it was held for 3 h, yielding the M-CeO₂-CX derivative of the MOF-808(Ce)-X sample. 2.2 Experimental design The optimization of the reaction conditions for DMC synthesis was conducted using BP experiments, BBD experiments and RSM. Statistical analysis was performed to investigate the effects of various parameters, including reaction time (0.5–12 h), reaction temperature (100–180 °C), feed ratio of CH₃OH/CO₂ (1.33–19.2 g/MPa), catalyst loading (0.05–1.25 g) and rotation rate (100–600 rpm). The yield of the synthesized DMC was evaluated using Eq. (1), ultimately identifying the optimal values for the significant influencing factors and predicting a regression model. In this study, the BP experiments were utilized to assess the contribution of each influencing factor to the DMC yield, employing a second-order polynomial (Eq. (2)) to correlate five independent variables with the DMC yield, thereby determining the optimal values for each variable. This also provided a basis for the design of the BBD experiments. The BBD experiments were aimed at evaluating the primary influencing factors, ensuring that all scenarios were considered, which facilitated the construction of the response surface and enhanced the accuracy of the predictive model. (2), y represents the predicted response, while β0 denotes the intercept term. The coefficients βi, βii and βij correspond to the variables' linear, quadratic, and interaction coefficients, respectively. The term xi signifies the independent variables, with xi xj (where (i < j)) representing the interaction between two variables. The variable k is the number of factors. Design Expert software (Version 13.0.1.0) was employed to design the experiments and analyze the output data. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity of M-CeO2-C0.5 According to Scheme 1 , MOF-808(Ce) underwent controlled alkaline etching, designated as MOF-808 (Ce)-X, where X represents the concentration of the alkaline solution (ranging from 0 to 1 M). Following this, a series of calcined samples, referred to as M-CeO₂-CX, were prepared. FT-IR spectra (Fig. S4) for MOF-808(Ce) and MOF-808(Ce)-0.5 exhibited characteristic absorption bands at 1630 cm−1 and 1400–1600 cm−1, attributed to CO stretching and aromatic ring vibrations, respectively. Post-etching, both peaks reduced intensity, indicating partial degradation of the aromatic ring structure in MOF-808(Ce). PXRD analysis (Fig. 1 (c)) of MOF-808(Ce)-0.5 and the calcined samples subjected to various etching treatments revealed that the crystalline framework of MOF-808(Ce)-0.5 remained intact after treatment with 0.5 M NaOH. However, upon increasing the etching concentration to 0.8 M, the topological structure was substantially collapsed (Fig. S5). The progressive intensification of PXRD peaks in the M-CeO₂-CX series, corresponding to increasing etching concentrations, confirmed a greater exposure of Ce active sites. The localization of electrons in the Ce 4f orbitals imparts a higher protonation capability to Ce compared to C, thereby significantly improving its efficiency in catalyzing methanol activation. For the purpose of assessing the catalytic performance of the synthesized catalysts, which were applied to the synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO2. Fig. 1(a) illustrates the impact of the M-CeO₂-CX catalysts on the DMC synthesis yield. As shown, the catalytic activity of M-CeO₂-C₀.₅ was optimal at a NaOH concentration of 0.5 M. Furthermore, catalysts H-CeO₂ and R-CeO₂-0.5 were synthesized using the method proposed by Kuan et al. (Support Information for detailed) [33], and a comparative activity analysis revealed that M-CeO₂-C0.5 exhibited significantly higher catalytic activity than the other two catalysts. In order to better understand the mechanisms underlying the enhanced catalytic activity, PXRD diffraction peaks and SEM surface morphologies of CeO₂ catalysts synthesized via various preparation methods were presented in Figs. 1(d), 2 and S1, respectively. The SEM images of the synthesized MOF-808(Ce)-0.5 and M-CeO2-C0.5 exhibited defect-rich rod-like structures (Fig. 2(a) (b)). The length distribution of the nanorod catalysts exhibited virtually unchanged before and after the calcination (Fig. S2). However, following calcination, internal carbon vacancies generated by alkaline etching (Scheme 1) became exposed, resulting in a rough surface characterized by pronounced defects on the nanorods (Fig. 2(b)). Additionally, M-CeO₂-C₀.₅, R-CeO₂-0.5 and H-CeO₂ can all be classified under CeO₂ (PDF# 89-8436), which exhibits a cubic fluorite structure (Fm3m(225)), as illustrated in Fig. 1(d). The crystallinity of CeO₂ was notably high for the (111), (200), (220) and (311) planes. A comparative analysis of the PXRD diffraction peaks (Fig. 1(d)) revealed the following order of crystallinity: M-CeO2-C0. 5 > H-CeO2 > R-CeO2-0.5. Obviously, the M-CeO₂-C₀.₅ catalyst presented a greater crystal surface area for the exposure of active sites and demonstrated the highest stability. Furthermore, the average crystal size of the catalyst was estimated using the Scherrer equation (S1)(S2), as detailed in Table 1 . The particle size hierarchy is M-CeO₂-C₀.₅ < R-CeO₂-0.5 < H-CeO₂. As we all know, smaller particle dimensions result in broader diffraction peaks, which correlate with an increase in crystal defects and grain boundaries. In addition, three-dimensional images revealed the surface charge density (Figs. 2(c) (d) and S1 (c) (d)), elucidating the intricate relationship between defects and charge distribution. Importantly, a higher defect density is associated with a more extensive charge distribution, leading to elevated charge density near the defects, thereby enhancing the adsorption of reactant molecules on the catalyst surface. Further, to thoroughly analyze the impact of alkaline-etched MOF-808 (Ce) precursors on the catalyst's internal morphology and investigate how these structural alterations directly influence its catalytic performance. Three different catalysts were systematically investigated through XPS, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and corresponding BJH pore size distribution analysis, as detailed in Table 1 and Fig. 3 . For the Ce 3d peaks, the binding energy positions of the three catalysts are as follows: M-CeO₂-C0. 5 < R-CeO₂-0.5 < H-CeO₂. The shift toward lower binding energy is attributed to the increased electron density around the defect sites, which is indicative of a higher percentage of Ce³⁺. The detailed quantitative analysis using formulas S4 and S5 allows for the determination of Ce3+ and Ce4+ proportions relative to total Ce content, as analysized in Table 1. The proportion of Ce3+ follows the order: M-CeO2-C0. 5 > R-CeO2-0.5 > H-CeO2. Concurrently, oxygen vacancy (OV) concentrations calculated using formula S3 show a similar trend: M-CeO2-C0. 5 > R-CeO2-0.5 > H-CeO2. This consistency is explained by OV inducing neighboring oxygen atoms to gain two electrons, reducing adjacent Ce4+ to Ce3+. Regarding oxygen binding energies, the order is R-CeO2-0.5 < M-CeO2-C0. 5 < H-CeO2. This shift towards the higher binding energies compared to R-CeO2-0.5 is attributed to reduced electron density around oxygen atoms near defect sites. Modification-induced hybridization of Ce-O orbitals redistributes electrons, which intensifies surface interactions with CO2. The moderate oxygen binding energies indicate stronger adsorption interactions that are conducive to catalytic reactions. Considering BET-specific surface areas, the order is R-CeO2-0.5 < M-CeO2-C0. 5 < H-CeO2. This observation confirmed that the exposed surface area of the catalysts does not solely dictate their catalytic efficacy. Additionally, the thorough analysis of average pore size and the total pore volume indicated that not all pore sizes contributed equally to CO2 and DMC adsorption. Fig. 3 highlighted that micropores in M-CeO2-C0.5 predominantly facilitate adsorption during the DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol. The N₂ adsorption-desorption isotherms provided further insight into the strength of physical adsorption. H-CeO₂ displayed a type III isotherm, characteristic of non-porous metal oxides, where the interaction between H-CeO₂ and the adsorbate N₂ is notably weaker than the intermolecular interactions among the N₂ molecules themselves. This finding suggested that the physical adsorption of reactants onto the H-CeO₂ catalyst was relatively weak. In contrast, both R-CeO₂-0.5 and M-CeO₂-C0.5 exhibited type V isotherms, featuring hysteresis loops with inflexion points at higher relative pressures. This behavior reflected van der Waals interactions between the adsorbates and the microporous as well as mesoporous solid catalysts. Notably, the physical adsorption strength in R-CeO₂-0.5 and M-CeO₂-C0.5 exceeded that of H-CeO₂. Interestingly, M-CeO₂-C0.5 showed a pronounced rise in the isotherm at high relative pressures, indicating a greater presence of micropores. This observation was supported by shifts in the binding energy of oxygen from the XPS analysis and the BJH pore size distribution results, further highlighting the intricate relationship between pore structure and catalytic performance. As shown in Table 2 and Fig. 4 (a), a CO₂-TPD analysis was carried out on three distinct catalysts to explore the role of the alkali-treated Ce precursor on the M-CeO₂-C0.5 catalyst's performance. Comparative analysis revealed the following order of basic strength among the catalysts: R-CeO₂-0.5 (0.384 mmol/g) < H-CeO₂ (0.509 mmol/g) < M-CeO₂-C0.5 (0.692 mmol/g). The M-CeO₂-C0.5 catalyst exhibited the highest basicity and density of basic sites. Compared to H-CeO₂ and R-CeO₂-0.5, the enhanced basicity and abundant basic sites on M-CeO₂-C0.5—including OL and OH groups from incompletely calcined Ce-OH(OH)2—played a significant role in the adsorption and activation of CO₂. On the catalyst surface, the OL surrounding OV clusters had a higher electron cloud density, facilitating the attraction and activation of the carbon atom in CO₂ molecules. Additionally, two adjacent Ce³⁺ sites could act as proton donors for the oxygen atoms in CO₂, enabling deeper activation of the molecule. However, the activated intermediates experienced overly strong adsorption at high - basicity sites, making desorption difficult. Therefore, the catalytic reaction predominantly occurred at sites with moderate and weak adsorption strengths. According to Table 2, the basicity of M-CeO₂-C0.5 at both moderate and weak adsorption sites was significantly higher than that of the other two catalysts. This trend was further validated by Fig. 4(a), where M-CeO₂-C0.5 demonstrated stable CO₂ desorption peaks in both low- and high-temperature regions, indicative of excellent thermal stability and the ability to maintain catalytic activity across a wide temperature range. Furthermore, the analysis of CO₂ desorption peak areas suggested that, in the low-temperature region, the basic site strength of M-CeO₂-C0.5 exceeded that of R-CeO₂-0.5. This result implies that M-CeO₂-C0.5 possesses more basic sites and superior chemisorption capabilities compared to the other two catalysts. These characteristics contribute to the enhanced CO₂ selectivity of M-CeO₂-C0.5 in DMC synthesis, making it a more suitable catalyst for this reaction. 3.2 Results of the study of kinetic and thermodynamic parameters The synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO₂ over a catalyst is a delicate interplay of thermodynamic and kinetic factors. With the reactor volume fixed at 100 mL, the key thermodynamic variables are temperature and pressure. Since the reaction proceeds in the gas phase, while the feedstocks—CO₂ and methanol—are introduced as liquids, vaporization occurs as the temperature rises. As a result, system pressure becomes heavily dependent on the feed ratio, positioning it as a critical thermodynamic parameter in the reaction process. For kinetic parameters, reaction time and reactor rotation rate were selected. Additionally, since the MOF-808(Ce) precursor alters the distribution of active sites on the catalyst, the required catalytic doses for the reaction were evaluated. The PB experiment was carried out to systematically investigate the primary influence factors, as illustrated in Fig. 5 . The experiments were conducted with varying levels of reaction time (0.5–4 h), reaction temperature (130–180 °C), feed ratio of CH₃OH/CO₂ (1.33–19.2 g/MPa), catalyst dosage (0.05–0.35 g) and rotation rate (300–600 rpm). The results indicated that DMC yield increased with higher temperature, CH₃OH/CO₂ feed ratio and rotation rate. In contrast, it decreased with an increase in catalyst dosage and reaction time. Regardless of the interaction, we acquired a single-factor regression equation (Eq. (3)) to describe the relationship between DMC yield and each factor. The magnitude of the regression coefficients signifies the strength of each variable's influence on the yield, while the sign indicates whether the effect is positive or negative. Further, the analysis of variance (ANOVA) results offered critical insights into the role and significance of each variable, as well as the reliability of the selected model (Table S3). The model's high F-value of 10.93 and a P-value of 0.0057 (below 0.05) indicate that the model is statistically significant. Additionally, the slight difference between the Predicted R 2 and Adjusted R 2, which is less than 0.2, further confirmed the model's robustness. With an Adeq Precision value of 10.86, substantially higher than 4, the model was shown to have sufficient precision to measure the signal-to-noise ratio, making it suitable for accurately correlating the five influencing factors with the DMC yield (detailed data are provided in the supplementary materials). The consistency between Eq. (3) and the results depicted in Fig. 5 led to the determination of the optimal conditions for the reaction: a reaction temperature of 179 °C, a rotation rate of 588 rpm, a reaction time of 0.7 h, a catalyst dosage of 0.06 g, and a CH₃OH/CO₂ feed ratio of 22.89 g/MPa. These parameters yield a corresponding DMC production of 24.61 mmol/g cat. h. (3) Sqrt ( DMC yield ) = 0.6390 + 1.02 A + 0.6830 B − 0.7218 C − 1.47 D + 1.51 E (4) DMC yield = 0.3110 + 1.22 A + 1.23 B + 0.4811 C + 3.55 AB + 1.09 AC + 1.97 A 2 + 2.01 B 2 As illustrated in Fig. 5, the reactor's temperature, feed ratio, and rotation rate represent the most significant influence factors. The synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol is driven by both thermodynamics and kinetics. However, thermodynamics exerts a more pronounced influence on the experiment than kinetics. In line with the observed influence trend, further examination of the interaction was conducted through BBD experiments to quantify the results precisely. Subsequently, a BBD experiment was conducted to acquire the primary three influence factors, ensuring RSM's comprehensive nature to determine the optimal reaction conditions. The designed table and recorded reaction pressures are presented in Table S2, while the experimental results are depicted in Fig. 6 . The results of the analysis of variance (ANOVA) in Table S3 provide a comprehensive assessment of the model's fitness and the influence of significant variables, as well as their interactions, on the desired response. It is evident from the ANOVA outcomes that the proposed model (2FI and quadratic) demonstrates a significant effect on the DMC yield, as indicated by a p-value of less than 0.0001. This statistical significance suggests that the model can predict the system's response with a high degree of accuracy. In ANOVA, a p-value less than 0.05 indicates that a model term is significant and must be included in the response prediction. In particular, the terms associated with reaction temperature, CH₃OH/CO₂ feed ratio, rotation rate, the interaction between reaction temperature and rotation rate (AC) and the interaction between reaction temperature and feed ratio (AB) are crucial for the proposed models. Moreover, the quadratic terms for reaction temperature (A2) and CH₃OH/CO₂ feed ratio (B2) also play significant roles in the quadratic model. Other interaction and quadratic terms were found to be insignificant (p-value >0.05) and were therefore excluded from the equation. Eq. (4) represents the simplified final polynomial model. The lack-of-fit value serves as a measure of the model's adequacy, and in this case, a lack-of-fit p-value greater than 0.05 suggests that the model does not exhibit a significant lack-of-fit. Thus, it can be concluded that the proposed model fits the experimental data well. To further validate the robustness and predictive capability of the model, the predicted R 2 and adjusted R 2 parameters were examined. For both models, the difference between predicted R2 and adjusted R2 is less than 0.2, confirming the predictive power of the models. Adequate precision measures the signal-to-noise ratio, and according to statistical guidelines, the value should exceed 4. In this case, the DMC yield model has an adequate precision value of 42.5993, well above the threshold of 4, indicating a strong signal, thus, sufficient reliability for prediction. The predictive model's accuracy and reliability are typically evaluated through a graphical comparison of actual experimental data versus predicted values. For DMC yield, as depicted in Fig. 6(a), the data points exhibit a uniform and random distribution around the X = Y parity line, signifying that the model adequately captures the experimental data. This even distribution demonstrates that the model successfully represents the relationship between the input variables and the corresponding response. Consequently, the proposed model is highly effective for exploring the design space, offering robust and reliable predictions within the defined experimental parameters. The impact of operational variables on the response varies, as depicted in the three-dimensional surface plots in Fig. 6(b)–(d). These plots indicate that the DMC yield surpasses the CH₃OH/CO₂ feed ratio. Additionally, an analysis of the pressure behavior during the reaction of different feedstocks over time suggests that pressure increases as the solubility of CO₂ in methanol rises with increasing reaction pressure. Notably, when the pressure exceeds the CO₂ critical point of 7.39 MPa, the solubility of CO₂ in methanol significantly increases. Furthermore, at higher CH₃OH/CO₂ ratios, increasing the reaction temperature or rotation rate further enhances the DMC yield. This improvement can be attributed to the increase in effective molecular collisions and enhanced rotation rate, which increases entropy (∆S) and decreases Gibbs free energy (∆G), facilitating the reaction and boosting DMC production. On the other hand, increasing the rotation rate at lower reaction temperatures does not significantly influence the DMC yield. A comparison of Fig. 6(b) and (d) highlights that the reaction temperature has the most substantial influence on DMC synthesis, mainly because the thermodynamic favorability of bond formation between the reactants strengthens at elevated temperatures, stabilizing the product. However, it is important to note that temperatures exceeding 200 °C can lead to the decomposition of DMC into CO₂ and dimethoxy ether [34,35]. Therefore, avoiding side reactions and optimizing conditions are essential to achieve the maximum DMC yield. Beyond the activity measurements, the stability of the prepared catalysts for the title reaction was also examined by catalyst recycling experiment (Fig. 5(b)). Under the optimal conditions, the M-CeO2-C0.5 catalyst was recycled 12 times. Interestingly, the catalyst exhibited exceptional recyclability, maintaining a stability of 97.88 %. In conjunction with Table S4, a comparison of catalysts employed for the direct synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO2, without the incorporation of dehydrating agents, reveals that M-CeO2-C0.5 has significant industrial potential. 4 Conclusions The objective of this study is to synthesize DMC directly via CO2 and methanol in a laboratory-scale reactor, and evaluate the catalytic activity of the M-CeO2-C0.5 catalyst synthesized by the DMC yield. (I) A series of alkali-modified MOF-808(Ce) samples were developed with varying concentrations. And successive carbonation reactions were conducted to yield M-CeO₂-CX. It was found that the most suitable alkaline preparation environment for cutting the non-covalent interactions between Ce-BTC organic ligands was 0.5 M NaOH. (II) Some characterization techniques were employed to validate the efficacy of the microporous defect derivatization strategy, which confirmed that derivatization by alkaline-etched MOF-808(Ce) significantly enhances Ov concentrations and the density of basic sites, which are significantly crucial for CO₂ and methanol chemisorption activation, thereby augmenting the material's catalytic performance. (III) A comprehensive investigation of the kinetic and thermodynamic parameters was conducted using PB experimental methodologies. The results revealed that thermodynamic driving forces had more impacts on the reaction than kinetic factors. (IV) The meticulously developed yield prediction models have led to the discovery of optimal reaction conditions: a reaction temperature of 179 °C, a rotation rate of 588 rpm, a reaction time of 0.7 h, a catalyst doses of 0.06 g and a CH3OH/CO2 feed ratio of 22.89 g/MPa. These precise parameters are instrumental in maximizing yield and efficiency. (V) BBD experimental methodologies was employed to explore interaction between these variables; the interaction between temperature and pressure plays a crucial role in the reaction. (VI) Under these optimized conditions, the catalytic system achieved a predicted DMC yield of up to 24.61 mmol/g cat. h, maintaining a stability of 97.88 %. We developed a comprehensive framework for the design and optimization of catalysts derived from MOFs. It emphasizes the pivotal role of integrating sophisticated characterization techniques with meticulously structured experimental designs to significantly enhance catalytic performance. The results presented herein contribute to the progression of efficient catalytic systems for CO2 utilization, highlighting their potential for scalable industrial applications and substantial environmental advantages. coredata.dc:description: To achieve higher yields of dimethyl carbonate (DMC), it is crucial to have precise control of reaction conditions and to develop advanced catalysts with synergistic interactions at active sites. In this work, we synthesized a series of alkali-modified MOF-808 (Ce) catalysts by varying NaOH concentrations (0–1.0 M), followed by carbonation to yield the advanced catalysts—M-CeO₂-CX. Our evaluations of catalytic performance revealed that a 0.5 M NaOH alkaline environment (M-CeO₂-C0.5) was the most effective in breaking the non-covalent interactions within Ce-BTC ligands. Comprehensive characterization further confirmed that M-CeO₂-C0.5 exhibited markedly increased oxygen vacancies and higher densities of basic sites. Both of them are pivotal for enhancing CO₂ activation, leading to superior catalytic performance. Particularly, it was also applied, for the first time, in the direct synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO₂ without a dehydrating agent. Using Plackett-Burman (PB) and Box–Behnken Design (BBD) experimental techniques, we demonstrated that thermodynamic forces significantly outweighed kinetic effects in driving the reaction. Additionally, predictive yield models were developed and rigorously validated, identifying optimal conditions that resulted in a DMC yield of 24.61 mmol/g cat•h. Remarkably, the catalyst retained 97.88 % of its initial activity after 12 cycles, underscoring its exceptional stability and promising industrial scalability.
